Acceleration of a Fluid (page 84)

Take the Cartesian components of $\q$ as $[u,v,w]$. Then the x-component of the acceleration is \dfrac{du}{dt}= & \dpartialwrt[u]{t} \dpartialwrt[t]{t} &+& \dpartialwrt[u]{x} \dpartialwrt[x]{t}& +& \dpartialwrt[u]{y} \dpartialwrt[y]{t} &+& \dpartialwrt[u]{z} \dpartialwrt[z]{t} \\ = & \dpartialwrt[u]{t} &+& \dpartialwrt[u]{x} u &+& \dpartialwrt[u]{y} v &+& \dpartialwrt[u]{z} w \\ = & \dpartialwrt[u]{t} &+& u \dpartialwrt[u]{x} &+& v \dpartialwrt[u]{y} &+& w \dpartialwrt[u]{z}\\ = & \dpartialwrt[u]{t} & +& (\q . \grad) u \\ \mbox{Similarly, } \dfrac{dv}{dt} =& \dpartialwrt[v]{t} & +& (\q . \grad) v \\ \mbox{and } \dfrac{dw}{dt} =& \dpartialwrt[w]{t} & +& (\q . \grad) w \\ \mbox{Hence } f=\dfrac{d \q}{dt} =& \dpartialwrt[\q]{t} &+& (\q . \grad)\q

(\q.\grad)=& u\dpartialwrt{x} &+& v \dpartialwrt{y} &+& w \dpartialwrt{x} \\ =& (\q.\hat{i})\dpartialwrt{x} &+& (\q.\hat{j}) \dpartialwrt{y} &+& (\q.\hat{k}) \dpartialwrt{x} \\ =& \sum (\q.\hat{i}) \dpartialwrt{x} \\ (\q.\grad)\q =& \sum (\q.\hat{i}) \dpartialwrt[q]{x}\\
\mbox{Since } A \times (B \times C) = & (A.C) B &-& (A.B)C\\ (A.B)C = & (A.C)B &-& A \times (B \times C)\\ (q.\hat{i})\dpartialwrt[q]{x} =& \bracket{q.\dpartialwrt[q]{x}} \hat{i} &-& q \times (\hat{i} \times \dpartialwrt[q]{x})\\ (q.\hat{i})\dpartialwrt[q]{x} =& \bracket{\dpartialwrt{x}\bracket{\dfrac{1}{2}q^2}} \hat{i} &-& q \times (\hat{i} \times \dpartialwrt[q]{x})\\ \dsum (q.\hat{i})\dpartialwrt[q]{x} =& \dsum \bracket{\dpartialwrt{x}\bracket{\dfrac{1}{2}q^2}} \hat{i} &-& q \times \dsum \bracket{\hat{i} \times \dpartialwrt[q]{x}}\\ (q.\grad)q = & \grad \bracket{\dfrac{1}{2} q^2} &-& q \times (\grad \times q)

$$\begin{align*} \mbox{Hence } f=\dfrac{d \q}{dt} &= \dpartialwrt[\q]{t} + (\q . \grad)\q\\ &= \dpartialwrt[\q]{t} + \grad \bracket{\frac{1}{2} q^2} - q \times (\grad \times q) \end{align*}$$
